critique: This executive order lists communicable diseases that allow for the apprehension, detention, or conditional release of individuals to prevent the spread of communicable diseases. It also revokes three older executive orders. There is no direct indication of ideological tilt. It does not directly address immigration. It could be argued that it expands executive power to detain individuals, but this is within the scope of public health. It does not obviously relate to federalism. It leans toward national security by prioritizing public health. It does not directly regulate the economy. It does not directly address social inclusion.
